Subsection.Text: A vessel that is engaged on a voyage beyond the limits of sea area A1 in an area where there is a broadcast of maritime safety information over medium frequency, such as by an international NAVTEX service, must be fitted with a NAVTEX receiver or another receiver that is compatible with the broadcast service, if it is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that carries more than six passengers;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a fishing vessel that is 24 m or more in length;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a towboat of 150 gross tonnage or more; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel of 300 gross tonnage or more.

Subsection.Text: A vessel that is not subject to the requirement of subsection (1) and that is engaged on a near coastal voyage, Class 1 or an unlimited voyage must have the necessary equipment to receive maritime safety information during the voyage.

Section.MarginalNote: Search and rescue VHF radio direction-finding apparatus
Section.Text: The following vessels must be fitted with a search and rescue VHF radio direction-finding apparatus:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a government vessel used for search and rescue; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a standby vessel used to provide transport or assistance to employees who are employed in connection with the exploration or drilling for, or the production, conservation, processing or transportation of, oil or gas.

Section.Text: The master and authorized representative of a vessel must ensure that the following documents and publications are kept on board in a readily accessible location:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the radio operator certificate for each of its the radio operators; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: at the main operating position of the radio installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Radio Aids to Marine Navigation published by the Canadian Coast Guard, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the radio inspection certificate for the radio installation, if a certificate is required by section 240.

Section.Text: A vessel that is 20 m or more in length must have an antenna plan that indicates the relative position of each antenna.
The main operating position of a radio installation must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a card of instructions, such as TP 9878, Distress and Safety Radiotelephone Procedures, published by the Department of Transport, visibly displayed, setting out a clear summary of the radio distress procedures;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the following items, stored so as to be easily accessible:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: instructions to enable the radio equipment to be properly operated, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the instructions, replacement parts and tools necessary to carry out routine maintenance and checks on the radio equipment, as recommended by the manufacturer or required under Division 2 of this Part, that may be performed by persons who are not radio technicians; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a visibly displayed, reliable and accurate device that indicates time.

Section.Text: A vessel referred to in subsection 204(1) that is 20 m or more in length and fitted with only one VHF radio installation capable of DSC must be equipped with a spare antenna accompanied by sufficient interconnecting cable to permit the fast replacement of the main antenna without retuning.
A vessel must have a supply of electrical energy sufficient to operate its radio installation and to charge any batteries used as part of the reserve source of energy for the radio installation.

Subsection.Text: A vessel that is 20 m or more in length, a vessel that carries more than six passengers or a towboat must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a reserve source of energy that meets the requirements of Division 2 of this Part and that is sufficient to supply its radio installation for the purpose of conducting distress and safety communications in the event of a failure of the main and emergency sources of electrical energy; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a permanently installed means for internally or externally lighting the radio controls that are necessary for the operation of its radio installation, independent of the main and emergency sources of electrical energy.

Subsection.Text: Subsection (1) does not apply to a vessel that carries more than six passengers or a towboat, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is less than 20 m in length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it is navigating in sea area A1; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: it is equipped with a survival craft VHF radiotelephone or a waterproof portable VHF handheld radio capable of DSC.

Subsection.Text: This Division, other than section 228, applies in respect of radio equipment, including documentation for the equipment, that a Canadian vessel must have on board under Division 1 of this Part, the Vessel Construction and Equipment Regulations, the Life Saving Equipment Regulations or the Large Fishing Vessel Inspection Regulations, as applicable.

Sections 219 and 223 and the requirement under subsection 240(3) to inspect the radio installation also apply in respect of any radio equipment, including documentation for the equipment, that a foreign vessel in Canadian waters must have on board under Division 1 of this Part, the Life Saving Equipment Regulations or the Large Fishing Vessel Inspection Regulations, as applicable.
Section 228 applies in respect of all EPIRBs and PLBs on board

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a Canadian vessel; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a pleasure craft that

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is licensed under Part 10 of the Act, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: is principally maintained or operated in Canada and is not registered or licensed under the laws of another state.

Section.Text: A radio installation must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: installed on board a vessel so as to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: protect it from mechanical, electrical or any other interference that would adversely affect its functioning,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: be compatible with other radio and electronic equipment installed on the vessel and not cause adverse electromagnetic or electrostatic interaction, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: be readily accessible for maintenance purposes and inspection;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: clearly marked with the vessel’s name, call sign, maritime mobile service identity number and any other identifier that may be used in the course of transmitting or receiving communications; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: located on a vessel so as to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: maximize its safety and operational accessibility,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: enable the monitoring of the distress and safety frequencies, including frequencies on which maritime safety information is broadcasted, and the sending of distress signals or distress alerts, from the position from which the vessel is normally navigated, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: protect it from the harmful effects of water, extremes of temperature and other adverse environmental conditions.

Section.Text: A VHF radiotelephone and a VHF radio installation must be accessible from the vessel’s conning position and its operation, including the selection of channels, must be possible from that position.

If radio equipment is capable of automatically providing the vessel’s position when transmitting a distress alert, the vessel’s position and the time the vessel was at that position must be made available from a GNSS receiver for transmission by the radio equipment.

Subsection.Text: The radio equipment referred to in column 1 of Schedule 3 must be of a type approved by a competent authority as meeting the following standards:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the performance standards set out in the Annex to IMO resolution A.694(17), General Requirements for Shipborne Radio Equipment Forming Part of the Global Maritime Distress and Safety System (GMDSS) and for Electronic Navigational Aids;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the testing standards set out in IEC 60945, Maritime Navigation and Radiocommunication Equipment and Systems – General Requirements – Methods of Testing and Required Test Results;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the standards set out for that equipment in column 2 of Schedule 3; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the standards set out for that equipment in column 3 or 4 of Schedule 3.

Subsection.Text: The equipment may be type approved by a competent authority as meeting a standard that provides a level of safety that is equivalent to or higher than that provided by the standards referred to in paragraph (1)(c) or (d) instead of the standards referred to paragraph (1)(c) or (d), as the case may be.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Exception — VHF radio installation capable of DSC
Subsection.Text: The VHF radio installation capable of DSC on board a vessel referred to in subsection 204(1) or paragraph 207(1)(b) may meet either of the following standards instead of the standards referred to in paragraphs (1)(c) and (d):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the testing standards set out in IEC 62238, Maritime Navigation and Radiocommunication Equipment and Systems – VHF Radiotelephone Equipment Incorporating Class “D” Digital Selective Calling (DSC) – Methods of Testing and Required Test Results; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the testing standards set out in EN 301 025: VHF Radiotelephone Equipment for General Communications and Associated Equipment for Class “D” Digital Selective Calling (DSC); Harmonised Standard Covering the Essential Requirements of Articles 3.2 and 3.3(g) of the Directive 2014/53/EU.

Subsection.Text: The type approval must be evidenced by a label or document issued by the competent authority.
The type approval must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if it is evidenced by a label, securely affixed to the equipment in a readily visible location; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if it is evidenced by a document, kept in a readily accessible location on board the vessel.

Subsection.Text: If the label or document is written in a language other than English or French, it must be accompanied by an English or French translation.

Section.MarginalNote: Portable VHF handheld radio with DSC

Subsection.Text: A portable VHF handheld radio capable of DSC must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of transmitting and receiving distress and safety alerts using DSC on frequency 156.525 MHz (channel 70);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of transmitting and receiving radiotelephony on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the distress and safety frequency of 156.8 MHz (channel 16),

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the primary inter-vessel safety communication frequency of 156.3 MHz (channel 6),

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the bridge-to-bridge communication frequency of 156.65 MHz (channel 13),

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: the public correspondence frequency specifically assigned for the area in which the vessel is navigating, and

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: any other VHF frequencies that are necessary for safety purposes in the area in which the vessel is navigating;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of receiving communications on

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a VHF frequency specifically assigned for the transmission of maritime safety information in the area in which the vessel is navigating, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: if no frequency is specifically assigned in the area in which the vessel is navigating, any other frequency used for transmitting maritime safety information;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: be certified as waterproof by the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: not be unduly affected by exposure to seawater, oil or the sun;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: be of robust mechanical construction;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: have an internal GNSS receiver capable of providing an accurate position within 90 seconds of being switched on, when provided with an unobstructed view of the sky; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of six hours of operation, with a duty cycle of 10% transmitting, 10% receiving above squelch level and 80% receiving below squelch level.

Subsection.Text: A portable VHF handheld radio capable of DSC that is powered by a rechargeable battery must be accompanied by a device capable of fully charging the battery from empty within 10 hours.
Any supplementary VHF radio installation that a vessel is fitted with under section 205 must be functionally independent from the VHF radio installation required under section 204.

The VHF radio installations referred to in subsection (1) may be connected to the main source of energy for the vessel, but one of them must have another source of energy that is located in the upper part of the vessel.

Section.Text: The antenna of a VHF radio installation must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: capable of transmitting and receiving a vertically polarized signal;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: installed as high as possible on a vessel and in such a manner as to provide an omnidirectional radiation pattern; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: connected to the radio installation by the shortest possible transmission line.

Subsection.Text: If batteries are the main source of energy for a VHF radio installation on board a vessel, the batteries must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be located in the upper part of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: have sufficient capacity to operate the VHF radio installation; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: be accompanied by a device capable of fully charging the batteries from empty within 10 hours.

Subsection.Text: If it is impracticable to locate the batteries in the upper part of a vessel whose construction began before June 1, 1978 or that is less than 20 m in length, they must be located as high in the hull as is possible.

Section.Text: An MF/HF radio installation’s transmitter on board a vessel must be capable of delivering 125 W peak envelope power at the output of the transmitter.

Subsection.Text: The authorized representative of a vessel, or in the case of a pleasure craft that is not a Canadian vessel, the owner of the vessel, must register an EPIRB or PLB with the Canadian Beacon Registry, which is maintained by the Department of National Defence.

The authorized representative or the owner, as the case may be, must update the information contained in the Canadian Beacon Registry with respect to the registration within 30 days after a change in the information.

Every EPIRB and PLB must be of a type approved by Cospas-Sarsat as meeting the requirements of standard C/S T.007 entitled Cospas-Sarsat 406 MHz Distress Beacons Type Approval Standard, published by Cospas-Sarsat.
The type approval referred to in subsection (1) must be evidenced by a type approval certificate that is kept in a readily accessible location on board.

Section.MarginalNote: Replacing the automatic release mechanism — EPIRB

Subsection.Text: The automatic release mechanism of an EPIRB must be marked with the replacement date determined by the manufacturer and be replaced on or before that date in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Replacing the battery — EPIRB and PLB
Subsection.Text: The battery of an EPIRB and the battery of a PLB must be replaced in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: after the use of the EPIRB or PLB in an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: after an inadvertent activation of the EPIRB or PLB;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if required as a result of an inspection or testing of the EPIRB or PLB; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: on or before the expiry date indicated on the battery.

Section.Text: The battery of a SART must be replaced in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions on or before the expiry date indicated on the battery.
A battery used to power a survival craft VHF radiotelephone must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the battery is non-rechargeable, be replaced, on or before the expiry date indicated on the battery; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the battery is rechargeable, be maintained in a fully charged condition while the vessel is at sea and the radiotelephone is not being used for communication purposes.

Section.MarginalNote: Search and rescue VHF radio direction-finding equipment
Section.Text: Search and rescue VHF radio direction-finding equipment must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of receiving amplitude-modulated signals on frequency 121.5 MHz;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: be capable of receiving frequency or phase-modulated signals on frequency 156.8 MHz (channel 16); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: provide an automatic indication-of-direction signal that is received when the source of the signal is located within an arc of 30° on either side of the vessel’s bow.

Subsection.Text: If a vessel is required to have a reserve source of energy under section 217, the reserve source must be capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: being used immediately in the event of a failure of the main source of electrical energy; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: simultaneously operating

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the VHF radio installation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the lighting required under paragraph 217(1)(b), and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: the radio equipment that the vessel must be fitted with under paragraph 207(1)(b), in the case of a vessel referred in that paragraph.

Subsection.Text: The reserve source of energy must have a capacity to provide electrical energy for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one hour, if the radio equipment is provided with an emergency source of electrical energy that meets the standards set out in TP 127, Ship Electrical Standards, published by the Department of Transport; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: six hours, in any other case.

Subsection.Text: The electrical capacity of the reserve source of energy under distress conditions must, for the period prescribed in subsection (2), be equal to the total of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one half of the electrical capacity necessary for the transmission of communications,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the electrical capacity necessary for the continuous reception of communications, and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the electrical capacity necessary for the continuous operation of any additional radio equipment or lighting connected to that reserve source of energy.

Subsection.Text: The reserve source of energy must be independent of the propelling power of the vessel and the vessel’s electrical system.
The reserve source of energy must, for the period prescribed by subsection (2), be capable of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: simultaneously supplying energy to all radio installations that can be connected to the reserve source of energy at the same time; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if only one radio installation can be connected to the reserve source of energy at the same time as a VHF radio installation, supplying energy to the radio installation that uses the most power.

Subsection.Text: The reserve source of energy must be used to supply the electrical lighting for a radio installation unless the electrical lighting has an independent source of energy that meets the capacity requirements set out in subsection (2).

Section.MarginalNote: Reserve source of energy — rechargeable batteries

Subsection.Text: If the reserve source of energy consists of rechargeable batteries, a vessel must have

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a means of recharging the batteries from empty to the minimum capacity required within 10 hours; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: for a vessel that is less than 20 m in length, a reserve battery of a capacity sufficient for the duration of the voyage.

Subsection.Text: Rechargeable batteries that constitute the reserve source of energy for a radio installation must be installed so that they

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are maintained at all times at the temperature specified by the manufacturer of the batteries; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide, when fully charged, the minimum number of hours of operation required by subsection 234(2), regardless of meteorological conditions.

Subsection.Text: If a radio installation requires an uninterrupted input of data from the vessel’s GNSS receiver in order to function properly, the radio installation must have a means to ensure that uninterrupted input of data in the event of a failure of the vessel’s main or emergency source of electrical energy.

Section.MarginalNote: Assessments and tests before a voyage
Section.Text: A radio operator must ensure that the radio equipment is in proper operating condition before the vessel embarks on a voyage.

Section.MarginalNote: Assessment of radio installation at sea

Subsection.Text: While a vessel is at sea, a radio operator must assess

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: daily the operating condition of a radio installation; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: subject to subsection (2), in the case of a VHF radio installation, MF radio installation or MF/HF radio installation, weekly by means of normal communications or a test call carried out within the communication range of either a radio installation or a coast station that is capable of DSC, the operating condition of the radio installation.

Subsection.Text: When a vessel has been out of the communication range of a radio installation or a coast station that is capable of DSC for longer than a week, a radio operator must make the test call at the first opportunity after the vessel is within the communication range of a coast station in order to assess the operating condition of the radio installation.
A radio operator must, when testing the operating condition of a radio installation transmitter, use the antenna normally used for the transmitter.

If an assessment referred to in subsection (1) or (2) indicates that the radio equipment or the reserve source of energy is not operating properly, the equipment or source of energy must be restored to its proper operating condition without delay.

If a radio installation is out-of-service for more than 30 days, a radio operator must verify, within the seven days before the vessel embarks on a voyage, that the radio equipment is in proper operating condition and must enter that information in the radio log.
If batteries constitute a source of electrical energy for radio equipment, other than an EPIRB or PLB, they must be

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: tested daily, to determine the state of their charge;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: checked once each month, to determine the physical condition of the batteries, their connections and their compartment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: sufficiently charged to permit the continuous operation of the radio equipment for the duration of the voyage.

Subsection.Text: Rechargeable batteries that constitute a reserve source of electrical energy for any radio equipment must undergo

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a check of their capacity, once a year, when the vessel is not at sea, by fully discharging and recharging them, using normal operating current and their battery rating period, unless the battery manufacturer advises otherwise; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an assessment of their charge without any significant discharge of the batteries immediately before the vessel embarks on a voyage, and weekly while at sea.

Section.MarginalNote: Inspection and testing of EPIRB or PLB

Subsection.Text: An EPIRB or PLB, other than an EPIRB or PLB stowed in an inflatable life raft, must be inspected and tested by a radio operator on installation and at least once every six months after that, in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Inspection and testing of a SART
Subsection.Text: A SART must be inspected and tested by a radio operator on installation and at least once every six months after that, in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.

A survival craft VHF radiotelephone must be tested by a radio operator during each boat and fire drill held on board the vessel, if the radiotelephone has a power source that can be replaced or recharged by the user.
The following vessels, other than a Safety Convention vessel, must have a radio inspection certificate to engage on a voyage:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is 20 m or more in length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a towboat; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger vessel that is engaged on a voyage any part of which is in Sea Area A1 or more than five nautical miles from shore on the sea coasts of Canada.

Subsection.Text: The master of a Safety Convention vessel must keep on board any safety certificate issued under subsection 7(1) of the Vessel Safety Certificates Regulations that relates to radio installation requirements.

The master of a vessel that is required to be inspected under the Agreement between Canada and the United States of America for Promotion of Safety on the Great Lakes by Means of Radio, 1973, must keep on board an inspection certificate issued by the Minister evidencing compliance with subsection 205(3) of these Regulations.
The Minister must issue a radio inspection certificate to a vessel if the radio installation meets the requirements of this Part.
Sections 242 to 248 apply in respect of Canadian vessels that are required under Division 1 of this Part to be fitted with radio equipment.
Sections 243 to 245, paragraph 246(1)(b) and subsection 246(2) also apply in respect of foreign vessels that are required under Division 1 of this Part to be fitted with radio equipment.

Sections 249 to 254 apply in respect of any vessel that is not a Canadian vessel in Canadian waters and in respect of any Canadian vessel that is required under Division 1 of this Part to be fitted with a VHF radio installation.

Section.Text: The master of a vessel and the person in charge of the deck watch must ensure that the requirements of this Division are met.

Section.MarginalNote: Communications of distress, urgency or safety
Section.Text: A vessel must make communications of distress, urgency or safety in accordance with the requirements of articles 32 to 34 of Chapter VII of the Radio Regulations that are published by the Secretary General of the International Telecommunication Union.

Section.MarginalNote: Cancellation of distress signals and alerts
Section.Text: A person who has inadvertently transmitted a distress alert from a vessel or, after transmitting an alert, determines that assistance is no longer required, must immediately cancel that alert in accordance with the instructions set out in the Appendix to IMO resolution A.814(19), Guidelines for the Avoidance of False Distress Alerts.
Except in a case of distress, a radio installation must not radiate more power than the power required to ensure clear communication.

Subsection.Text: A radio operator using a radio installation, must, when stating the time during voice communications on board a vessel, observe the time in the following manner:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is engaged on an international voyage, observe coordinated universal time (UTC); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if the vessel is engaged on any other type of voyage, observe the local time of the area in which the vessel is navigating.

Subsection.Text: A radio operator of a radio installation must, when stating the time, use the 24-hour system expressed by means of four figures from 00:01 to 24:00 followed by the time zone identifier.
A vessel must maintain a record in which the radio operator keeps the following information:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel’s name and registration number, its port of registry, gross tonnage and length and any of its Global Maritime Distress and Safety System identities as defined in Regulation 2 of Chapter IV of SOLAS;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the period covered by the record;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the time of each entry made in the radio record, stated in accordance with section 246;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a summary of all radio communications, including the date, time, frequency used and details with respect to

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: distress and urgency communications,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: safety communications respecting the vessel,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: abnormal radio propagation conditions that may reduce the effectiveness of the radio installation, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: any other important service incident;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the names of the radio operators, the dates each operator is on board and the name of each certificate that each radio operator holds;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the name of the radio operator designated for operating the radio equipment during emergencies as required under the Marine Personnel Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the date and time a check, test or inspection required under this Part was carried out and the results obtained including, for each day that the vessel is at sea,

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: the operating condition of the radio equipment determined by normal communication or a test call, as well as the position of the vessel at the time the determination is made,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: the assessment of the reserve source of energy, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: if any of the radio equipment is found not to be in operating condition, a notation that the master was informed;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the time of an inadvertent transmission of a distress, urgency or safety communication and the time and method of its cancellation;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the date, time and details of any significant maintenance carried out on the radio installation, including the name of the person or the company that performed the maintenance tasks; and

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: any corrective action taken to remedy any deficiency in the radio equipment required under this Part.

Subsection.Text: The radio operator making an entry in a radio record must initial the entry.

The radio record must be kept for a period of not less than 12 months after the day on which the last entry is made, in a place accessible to a marine safety inspector referred to in section 11 of the Act or a person, classification society or other organization authorized to carry out inspections under section 12 of the Act, and in the case of a paper record, it must be in its original format.

A vessel that is fitted with any of the following types of radio equipment must, while on a voyage, maintain a continuous watch on the frequencies specifically assigned for the transmission of maritime safety information that are appropriate to the time of day, the position of the vessel and the equipment carried:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a VHF radio installation;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an MF radio installation;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an MF/HF radio installation;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a NAVTEX receiver or other means that is used to automatically receive maritime safety information for visual display;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: enhanced group call equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: radio equipment capable of transmitting and receiving communications using NBDP.

Subsection.Text: A vessel fitted with an MF/HF radio installation may keep the continuous watch by means of a scanning receiver.

Section.Text: If, at any time, a radio transmission required to be made under these Regulations is prohibited by any other law or may cause a fire or an explosion, the transmission must be made as soon as it is permitted by that law and is not likely to cause a fire or an explosion.

Subsection.Text: The master of a vessel or a person authorized by the master to maintain a continuous listening watch or to make a navigation safety call required under this Division must be a radio operator.

If the person maintaining a continuous listening watch or making a navigation safety call is not the person in charge of the deck watch, they must, without delay, inform the person in charge of the deck watch of any information they receive or any navigation safety call they make that may affect the safe navigation of the vessel.

Section.Text: Nothing in this Division may be construed as relieving a vessel of its obligation under the provisions of the Collision Regulations to sound the appropriate whistle signals or as permitting the vessel to carry out manoeuvres that contravene the steering and sailing rules of those Regulations.

Subsection.Text: Every vessel that is required under section 204 to be fitted with a VHF radio installation must maintain a continuous listening watch during the period beginning 15 minutes before the vessel is underway and ending when the vessel is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: securely anchored, moored or made fast to the shore or secured to the bottom; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in a place where its presence does not constitute a hazard to passing vessels.

Subsection.Text: A VHF radio installation, referred to in subsection (1), on board a vessel described in column 1 of Schedule 4 must be set to the appropriate VHF channel set out in column 2 of that Schedule for that vessel and must operate with sufficient gain to permit an effective continuous listening watch.

If a vessel is not fitted with an additional VHF radio installation, the continuous listening watch referred to in subsection (1) may be interrupted for short periods while the installation is being used to transmit or receive communications on another channel.

Every vessel that is required under section 204 to have a VHF radio installation and that is a vessel described in column 1 of Schedule 4, other than a dredge or floating plant, must make a navigation safety call on the appropriate VHF channel set out in column 3 for that vessel, under the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a risk of collision with another vessel exists under the provisions of the Collision Regulations that apply in the area being navigated by the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the navigation safety call of another vessel indicates that a close-quarters situation may develop;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is in a narrow channel or fairway and is about to overtake another vessel, or be overtaken by another vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: doubt exists as to the actions or the intentions of another vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is nearing a bend in a river, channel or fairway or an obstruction around which an approaching vessel cannot adequately be seen;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is approaching, in restricted visibility, a charted route, including a ferry route, or a concentration of vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel will commence a manoeuvre that could impede the safe navigation of other vessels;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is engaged in fishing with nets, lines, trawls, trolling lines or other apparatus, or is a vessel restricted in its ability to manoeuvre in or near a routing system and is being approached by another vessel, other than a vessel engaged in fishing;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel is approaching a dredge or floating plant in or near a river, channel or fairway;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel will depart from a berth, anchorage, mooring area, booming ground, dredge or floating plant; and

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: under any other circumstance when a navigation safety call is necessary for the safe navigation of the vessel or any other vessel.

Subsection.Text: The navigation safety call required under the circumstances specified in paragraph (1)(j) must be made 15 minutes before and again immediately before departure from the berth, anchorage, mooring area, booming ground, dredge or floating plant.
The navigation safety call must not exceed one minute in duration and must contain only information that is essential for safe navigation, including the following, in sequence:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the location of the vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the intended course of action;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the present course and speed of the vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: whether the vessel is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: engaged in a towing operation,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: not under command,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: restricted in its ability to manoeuvre,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: engaged in fishing, other than trolling,

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: severely restricted in its ability to deviate from the course it is following because of its draft in relation to the available depth of water,

Subparagraph.Label: (vi)
Subparagraph.Text: engaged in pilotage duty,

Subparagraph.Label: (vii)
Subparagraph.Text: at anchor, or

Subparagraph.Label: (viii)
Subparagraph.Text: aground.

Subsection.Text: A vessel is not required to make a navigation safety call in the circumstances described in paragraph (1)(i) or (j) if the vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is a towboat and is manoeuvring in or around any berth, anchorage, mooring area, booming ground, dredge or floating plant and the vessel

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: manoeuvres in such a manner that it will not impede the safe navigation of other vessels, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: makes a navigation safety call 15 minutes before its final departure from that berth, anchorage, mooring area, booming ground, dredge or floating plant; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is reporting to a traffic centre.

Subsection.Text: The transmission power of a navigation safety call on Channel 13 within the Great Lakes Basin must not exceed 1 W except in the following cases when that power must not exceed 25 W:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an emergency;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the vessel being called to does not respond to a second call at a transmission power of 1 W or less; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a broadcast in blind situations such as when the vessel is rounding a bend in a channel.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Definition of vessel restricted in its ability to manoeuvre
Subsection.Text: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (3), vessel restricted in its ability to manoeuvre has the meaning assigned by the definition vessel restricted in her ability to manoeuvre in Rule 3(g) of Schedule 1 to the Collision Regulations.

Every dredge or floating plant that is required under section 204 to have a VHF radio installation and that is a vessel described in column 1 of Schedule 4 must make a navigation safety call on the appropriate VHF channel set out in column 3 for that vessel under the following circumstances:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: when approached by another vessel not engaged in an operation related to the dredge or floating plant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: when requested to do so by another vessel; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: under any other circumstance in which it is necessary for the safety of the dredge or floating plant or the safe navigation of any other vessel.

Subsection.Text: A navigation safety call referred to in subsection (1) must not exceed one minute in duration and must contain only information that is essential for safe navigation, including the following, in sequence:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the identity of the dredge or floating plant;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: its location; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a dredge or floating plant that is on a river, channel or fairway, to the extent possible, whether any part of the river, channel or fairway is obstructed and, if so, the side on which the obstruction exists and the side on which another vessel may pass.

Subsection.Text: A dredge or floating plant is not required to make a navigation safety call in the circumstances described in paragraph (1)(a) if it is reporting to a traffic centre.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in this Part.

Definition.Text: Assistant Commissioner means the Assistant Commissioner for the Central and Arctic Region, Department of Fisheries and Oceans. (commissaire adjoint)
Burlington Canal means the canal that links Lake Ontario and Hamilton Harbour. (canal de Burlington)
Captain of the Port means the Captain of the Port for the United States Coast Guard at Detroit, Michigan. (capitaine de port)
District Commander means the commander of the 9th District of the United States Coast Guard. (commandant du district)

Section.Text: It is prohibited for a vessel to anchor within the waters described in Schedule 5.

Every vessel within the waters described in Schedule 5 must comply with any instruction or direction relating to any navigation limitation or prohibition or other shipping measure contained in Notices to Mariners or a navigational warning.
It is prohibited for a vessel to navigate in the Burlington Canal at a speed greater than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: seven knots, if the vessel is 80 m or less in length; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the lowest speed at which the vessel can be navigated safely, if the vessel is more than 80 m in length.

Subsection.Text: A vessel heading towards the Burlington Canal must not, if it is within 0.5 nautical miles of the canal, pass another vessel going in the same direction.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of vessels that are less than 15 m in length.

Section.Text: If the person who has the conduct of a vessel requires the lift bridge over the Burlington Canal to be raised, the person must make a request to the bridgemaster by radio communication or, if such communication is not possible, the person must sound three long blasts on the whistle or horn.

Section.MarginalNote: Entry of vessel 15 m or more

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), it is prohibited for a vessel that is 15 m or more in length to enter the Burlington Canal unless the signal light on the lift bridge shows green in the direction of the vessel.

In the case of an emergency, a vessel that is 15 m or more in length may enter the Burlington Canal while the signal light on the lift bridge does not show green in its direction, but it must moor at the north wall of the canal and must not proceed until the signal light shows green in its direction.

Section.MarginalNote: Entry of vessel less than 15 m
Section.Text: It is prohibited for a vessel that is less than 15 m in length to enter the Burlington Canal while the lift bridge is not raised or while a flashing blue light is not shown in its direction, unless it waits at the side of the canal to its starboard at a distance of 90 m or more from the lift bridge until the bridge is raised or a flashing blue light is shown in its direction.
It is prohibited for a vessel to navigate under sail in the Burlington Canal.

Heading.Label: DIVISION 3
Heading.TitleText: St. Clair River and Detroit River

Subsection.Text: This Division, other than section 314, applies in respect of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: all vessels in Canadian waters between Lake Erie and Lake Huron; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: all Canadian vessels in the waters of the United States between buoy “1” of the East Outer and West Outer Channels at the Lake Erie entrance to the Detroit River and Lake Huron Cut Lighted Buoy “11” and including the Rouge River and Short Cut Canal from Detroit Edison Cell Light “1” to the head of navigation.

Subsection.Text: Section 311 does not apply in respect of a vessel referred to in subsection (1) unless the vessel is required under Part 2 to be fitted with a VHF radio installation or VHF radio telephone.
Sections 312 and 313 do not apply in respect of a vessel referred to in subsection (1) that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel engaged in icebreaking, search and rescue or servicing aids to navigation that is

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a government vessel,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: owned by and in the service of the government of the United States, or

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: in the exclusive possession of the government of the United States; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel engaged in river or harbour improvements, if it is operated in a safe and prudent manner and other vessels have been warned of those operations.

Subsection.Text: Section 314 applies in respect of a vessel referred to in subsection (1) that is

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a power-driven vessel that is 55 m or more in length;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel that is 20 m or more in length propelled only by sails;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a towboat; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a floating plant.

Section.Text: In the event of any inconsistency between this Division and the laws of the United States, the laws of the United States prevail to the extent of the inconsistency in respect of a Canadian vessel while it is in United States waters.

Every vessel must maintain a continuous listening watch in accordance with Radio Aids to Marine Navigation published by the Canadian Coast Guard and make traffic reports to the Canadian Coast Guard Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre located in Sarnia, Ontario, under the circumstances set out in that publication.

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for a vessel in the Detroit River to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: proceed upbound in the West Outer Channel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: proceed downbound in the Amherstburg Channel east of Bois Blanc Island;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: proceed upbound in the Livingstone Channel west of Bois Blanc Island; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: overtake another vessel between Bar Point Pier Light “D33” and Fighting Island South Light if there is a risk that the vessel will meet a third vessel proceeding in the opposite direction while the overtaking is taking place.

Subsection.Text: Despite paragraph (1)(b), the Assistant Commissioner may authorize a vessel to proceed downbound in the Amherstburg Channel east of Bois Blanc Island if the safety of navigation is not compromised.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for a vessel to overtake another vessel

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the St. Clair River between St. Clair Flats Canal Light “2” and Russell Island Light “33”, unless the vessel being overtaken is a towboat;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the Rouge River; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the Detroit River between the west end of Belle Isle and Peche Island Light, unless the vessel being overtaken

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: is a towboat; or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: has checked down its speed to await berth availability or to make the turn for Rouge River and has so advised the Canadian Coast Guard Marine Communications and Traffic Services Centre located in Sarnia, Ontario.

Section.Text: The waters between the St. Clair/Black River Junction Light and Lake Huron Cut Lighted Buoy “1” constitute an area of alternating one-way traffic where the following rules apply

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel must not, in that area, overtake or meet another vessel or come about;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a moored vessel must not get underway until it is able to proceed through those waters without passing or being passed by another vessel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a downbound vessel that has reached Lake Huron Cut Light “7” has the right-of-way over an upbound vessel that has not yet reached the St. Clair/Black River Junction Light; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an upbound vessel awaiting the transit of a downbound vessel must wait its turn below the St. Clair/Black River Junction Light.

Section.Text: It is prohibited for a vessel to embark, disembark or exchange a pilot between the St. Clair/Black River Junction Light and Lake Huron Cut Lighted Buoy “1” unless, because of the weather, it is unsafe to carry out that activity at the normal pilotage ground above Lake Huron Cut Lighted Buoy “1”.

Every vessel must, by using navigation safety calls, communicate its intentions to any other vessel in the vicinity and ensure that the movements of the vessels are coordinated and there is an agreement between the vessels before proceeding to overtake or meet the other vessel.
In the St. Clair and Detroit Rivers, it is prohibited for a vessel to anchor in such a manner that it could swing into the channel or across steering courses.

A floating plant may be operated, anchored or moored for the purposes of engaging in dredging, construction or wrecking only if the person having conduct of the floating plant obtains an authorization from the Assistant Commissioner, the District Commander, the Captain of the Port or the Windsor harbour master having jurisdiction in waters in which the floating plant will operate, anchor or moor, on such terms and conditions as are necessary to ensure the safety of navigation.
Except when required for the safety of the vessel or any other vessel, a vessel that is 20 m or more in length must not proceed at a speed greater than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: 10.4 knots between

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: Fort Gratiot and St. Clair Flats Canal Light “2”, and

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: Peche Island Light and Bar Point Pier Light “D33”;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 3.5 knots in the Rouge River; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: 5 knots in the navigable channel south of Peche Island.

Subsection.Text: It is prohibited for a towboat to drop or anchor its tows in such a manner that they could swing into a channel or across steering courses.
It is prohibited for a towboat engaged in arranging its tow to obstruct the navigation of other vessels.

Section.Text: Despite anything in this Division, a vessel must comply with temporary instructions to proceed in a certain manner or by a certain route, to anchor in a certain place or not to proceed or anchor except as specified in lieu of or in addition to any provisions of this Division if because of channel obstructions, a casualty, the weather, ice conditions, water levels or other unforeseen or temporary circumstances, compliance with this Division would be impossible, impracticable or unsafe or would cause a risk of pollution, and the instructions are

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: given by the Assistant Commissioner, in the case of Canadian waters, or the District Commander or the Captain of the Port, in the case of the waters of the United States; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: published in Notices to Mariners or a navigational warning.

Heading.Label: PART 4
Heading.TitleText: Transitional Provision, Consequential Amendments, Repeals and Coming into Force

Section.Text: Subsection 118(1) does not apply until 180 days after the day on which this section comes into force, except in the case of the following vessels in respect of which that subsection applies beginning on the day on which this section comes into force:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger vessel of 150 gross tonnage or more that is engaged on an international voyage;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel of 300 gross tonnage or more, other than a fishing vessel, that is engaged on an international voyage; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a vessel of 500 gross tonnage or more, other than a fishing vessel, that is not engaged on an international voyage.

The following Regulations are repealed:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
